natural problem: Julie baked cupcakes for her family at home and for a party at school. She iced 4 cupcakes with red frosting, 2 cupcakes with orange frosting, 2 with yellow, 2 with green, 3 with blue and the last 3 with violet frosting. Each cupcake is iced with exactly one color of frosting. Julie plans to take exactly 10 of the cupcakes to her party, and will take either all of the cupcakes of a particular color or none of the cupcakes of that color. How many different combinations of cupcakes could she take to her party?
natural solution: If Julie includes one of the colors that cover three cupcakes, she must also include the other color that covers three cupcakes. This is because she must make ten cupcakes total, and all of the other colors cover an even number of cupcakes, so there is no way to make ten with three and some combination of even numbers.

Thus, if she includes blue and violet, she has four cupcakes left to choose. There are three ways in which she can choose four cupcakes if she chooses colors that cover two (green and orange, green and yellow, or orange and yellow).
Alternately, she can choose a color that covers four (red). Finally, if she doesn't include any colors that cover three cupcakes, she must choose all of the other cupcakes in order to make ten.
Thus, Julie has $\boxed{5}$ different combinations of cupcakes.

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes red_cupcakes orange_cupcakes yellow_cupcakes green_cupcakes blue_cupcakes violet_cupcakes party_cupcakes :: nat
assumes h0 : "red_cupcakes = 4"
and h1 : "orange_cupcakes = 2"
and h2 : "yellow_cupcakes = 2"
and h3 : "green_cupcakes = 2"
and h4 : "blue_cupcakes = 3"
and h5 : "violet_cupcakes = 3"
and h6 : "party_cupcakes = 10"
and h7 : "(\<exists> n_red n_orange n_yellow n_green n_blue n_violet.
            n_red * red_cupcakes + n_orange * orange_cupcakes + n_yellow * yellow_cupcakes + n_green * green_cupcakes + n_blue * blue_cupcakes + n_violet * violet_cupcakes = party_cupcakes
            \<and> (n_red = 0 \<or> n_red = 1) \<and> (n_orange = 0 \<or> n_orange = 1) \<and> (n_yellow = 0 \<or> n_yellow = 1) \<and> (n_green = 0 \<or> n_green = 1) \<and> (n_blue = 0 \<or> n_blue = 1) \<and> (n_violet = 0 \<or> n_violet = 1))"
shows  "card {n. \<exists> n_red n_orange n_yellow n_green n_blue n_violet.
                  n_red * red_cupcakes + n_orange * orange_cupcakes + n_yellow * yellow_cupcakes + n_green * green_cupcakes + n_blue * blue_cupcakes + n_violet * violet_cupcakes = party_cupcakes
                  \<and> (n_red = 0 \<or> n_red = 1) \<and> (n_orange = 0 \<or> n_orange = 1) \<and> (n_yellow = 0 \<or> n_yellow = 1) \<and> (n_green = 0 \<or> n_green = 1) \<and> (n_blue = 0 \<or> n_blue = 1) \<and> (n_violet = 0 \<or> n_violet = 1)} = 5"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Julie baked cupcakes for her family at home and for a party at school. She iced 4 cupcakes with red frosting, 2 cupcakes with orange frosting, 2 with yellow, 2 with green, 3 with blue and the last 3 with violet frosting. Each cupcake is iced with exactly one color of frosting. Julie plans to take exactly 10 of the cupcakes to her party, and will take either all of the cupcakes of a particular color or none of the cupcakes of that color. How many different combinations of cupcakes could she take to her party? The final Answer is 5
 ### Proof
 If Julie includes one of the colors that cover three cupcakes, she must also include the other color that covers three cupcakes. This is because she must make ten cupcakes total, and all of the other colors cover an even number of cupcakes, so there is no way to make ten with three and some combination of even numbers.
 Thus, if she includes blue and violet, she has four cupcakes left to choose. There are three ways in which she can choose four cupcakes if she chooses colors that cover two (green and orange, green and yellow, or orange and yellow).
 Alternately, she can choose a color that covers four (red). Finally, if she doesn't include any colors that cover three cupcakes, she must choose all of the other cupcakes in order to make ten.
 Thus, Julie has $\boxed{5}$ different combinations of cupcakes.
 *)

theorem
fixes red_cupcakes orange_cupcakes yellow_cupcakes green_cupcakes blue_cupcakes violet_cupcakes party_cupcakes :: nat
assumes h0 : "red_cupcakes = 4"
and h1 : "orange_cupcakes = 2"
and h2 : "yellow_cupcakes = 2"
and h3 : "green_cupcakes = 2"
and h4 : "blue_cupcakes = 3"
and h5 : "violet_cupcakes = 3"
and h6 : "party_cupcakes = 10"
and h7 : "(\<exists> n_red n_orange n_yellow n_green n_blue n_violet.
            n_red * red_cupcakes + n_orange * orange_cupcakes + n_yellow * yellow_cupcakes + n_green * green_cupcakes + n_blue * blue_cupcakes + n_violet * violet_cupcakes = party_cupcakes
            \<and> (n_red = 0 \<or> n_red = 1) \<and> (n_orange = 0 \<or> n_orange = 1) \<and> (n_yellow = 0 \<or> n_yellow = 1) \<and> (n_green = 0 \<or> n_green = 1) \<and> (n_blue = 0 \<or> n_blue = 1) \<and> (n_violet = 0 \<or> n_violet = 1))"
shows  "card {n. \<exists> n_red n_orange n_yellow n_green n_blue n_violet.
                  n_red * red_cupcakes + n_orange * orange_cupcakes + n_yellow * yellow_cupcakes + n_green * green_cupcakes + n_blue * blue_cupcakes + n_violet * violet_cupcakes = party_cupcakes
                  \<and> (n_red = 0 \<or> n_red = 1) \<and> (n_orange = 0 \<or> n_orange = 1) \<and> (n_yellow = 0 \<or> n_yellow = 1) \<and> (n_green = 0 \<or> n_green = 1) \<and> (n_blue = 0 \<or> n_blue = 1) \<and> (n_violet = 0 \<or> n_violet = 1)} = 5"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: There are 4 red, 2 orange, 2 yellow, 2 green, 3 blue, and 3 violet cupcakes. We need to prepare 10 cupcakes for a party. We can choose to use either 0 or 1 of each color. How many different ways can we choose the cupcakes so that the total number of cupcakes is exactly 10? The final answer is 5.

a_1.formal problem:
theorem
fixes red_cupcakes orange_cupcakes yellow_cupcakes green_cupcakes blue_cupcakes violet_cupcakes total_cupcakes party_cupcakes :: nat
assumes h0 : "red_cupcakes = 4"
and h1 : "orange_cupcakes = 2"
and h2 : "yellow_cupcakes = 2"
and h3 : "green_cupcakes = 2"
and h4 : "blue_cupcakes = 3"
and h5 : "violet_cupcakes = 3"
and h6 : "total_cupcakes = red_cupcakes + orange_cupcakes + yellow_cupcakes + green_cupcakes + blue_cupcakes + violet_cupcakes"
and h7 : "party_cupcakes = 10"
and h8 : "\<forall>c1 c2 c3 c4 c5 c6. (c1 = 0 \<or> c1 = red_cupcakes) \<and> (c2 = 0 \<or> c2 = orange_cupcakes) \<and> (c3 = 0 \<or> c3 = yellow_cupcakes) \<and> (c4 = 0 \<or> c4 = green_cupcakes) \<and> (c5 = 0 \<or> c5 = blue_cupcakes) \<and> (c6 = 0 \<or> c6 = violet_cupcakes) \<and> (c1 + c2 + c3 + c4 + c5 + c6 = party_cupcakes) \<longrightarrow> (c1, c2, c3, c4, c5, c6) \<in> set (combinations :: (nat * nat * nat * nat * nat * nat) list)"
shows  "length (combinations) = 5"
a_1.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Julie baked cupcakes for her family at home and for a party at school. She iced 4 cupcakes with red frosting, 2 cupcakes with orange frosting, 2 with yellow, 2 with green, 3 with blue and the last 3 with violet frosting. Each cupcake is iced with exactly one color of frosting. Julie plans to take exactly 10 of the cupcakes to her party, and will take either all of the cupcakes of a particular color or none of the cupcakes of that color. How many different combinations of cupcakes could she take to her party? The final Answer is 5
 ### Proof
 If Julie includes one of the colors that cover three cupcakes, she must also include the other color that covers three cupcakes. This is because she must make ten cupcakes total, and all of the other colors cover an even number of cupcakes, so there is no way to make ten with three and some combination of even numbers.
 Thus, if she includes blue and violet, she has four cupcakes left to choose. There are three ways in which she can choose four cupcakes if she chooses colors that cover two (green and orange, green and yellow, or orange and yellow).
 Alternately, she can choose a color that covers four (red). Finally, if she doesn't include any colors that cover three cupcakes, she must choose all of the other cupcakes in order to make ten.
 Thus, Julie has $\boxed{5}$ different combinations of cupcakes.
 *)

theorem
fixes red_cupcakes orange_cupcakes yellow_cupcakes green_cupcakes blue_cupcakes violet_cupcakes total_cupcakes party_cupcakes :: nat
assumes h0 : "red_cupcakes = 4"
and h1 : "orange_cupcakes = 2"
and h2 : "yellow_cupcakes = 2"
and h3 : "green_cupcakes = 2"
and h4 : "blue_cupcakes = 3"
and h5 : "violet_cupcakes = 3"
and h6 : "total_cupcakes = red_cupcakes + orange_cupcakes + yellow_cupcakes + green_cupcakes + blue_cupcakes + violet_cupcakes"
and h7 : "party_cupcakes = 10"
and h8 : "\<forall>c1 c2 c3 c4 c5 c6. (c1 = 0 \<or> c1 = red_cupcakes) \<and> (c2 = 0 \<or> c2 = orange_cupcakes) \<and> (c3 = 0 \<or> c3 = yellow_cupcakes) \<and> (c4 = 0 \<or> c4 = green_cupcakes) \<and> (c5 = 0 \<or> c5 = blue_cupcakes) \<and> (c6 = 0 \<or> c6 = violet_cupcakes) \<and> (c1 + c2 + c3 + c4 + c5 + c6 = party_cupcakes) \<longrightarrow> (c1, c2, c3, c4, c5, c6) \<in> set (combinations :: (nat * nat * nat * nat * nat * nat) list)"
shows  "length (combinations) = 5"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_1.informal problem: There are 4 red, 2 orange, 2 yellow, 2 green, 3 blue, and 3 violet cupcakes. You need to choose a combination of 10 cupcakes for a party. Find the number of different combinations to choose the cupcakes, such that you either take all of a specific color or none of that color. The final answer is 5 different combinations.

a_2.formal problem:
theorem
fixes red_cupcakes orange_cupcakes yellow_cupcakes green_cupcakes blue_cupcakes violet_cupcakes total_cupcakes :: nat
assumes h0 : "red_cupcakes = 4"
and h1 : "orange_cupcakes = 2"
and h2 : "yellow_cupcakes = 2"
and h3 : "green_cupcakes = 2"
and h4 : "blue_cupcakes = 3"
and h5 : "violet_cupcakes = 3"
and h6 : "total_cupcakes = red_cupcakes + orange_cupcakes + yellow_cupcakes + green_cupcakes + blue_cupcakes + violet_cupcakes"
and h7 : "10 \<le> total_cupcakes"
shows  "\<exists> n. n = 5 \<and> (\<exists> A B C D E. card A = red_cupcakes \<and> card B = orange_cupcakes \<and> card C = yellow_cupcakes \<and> card D = green_cupcakes \<and> card E = blue_cupcakes \<and> (\<forall> F G H I J. card F = violet_cupcakes \<longrightarrow> (\<exists> K. card K = 10 \<and> ((K \<subseteq> A \<union> B \<union> C \<union> D \<union> E \<union> F \<union> G \<union> H \<union> I \<union> J) \<and> (\<forall> x \<in> K. x \<in> A \<or> x \<in> B \<or> x \<in> C \<or> x \<in> D \<or> x \<in> E \<or> x \<in> F \<or> x \<in> G \<or> x \<in> H \<or> x \<in> I \<or> x \<in> J))))))"
a_2.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Julie baked cupcakes for her family at home and for a party at school. She iced 4 cupcakes with red frosting, 2 cupcakes with orange frosting, 2 with yellow, 2 with green, 3 with blue and the last 3 with violet frosting. Each cupcake is iced with exactly one color of frosting. Julie plans to take exactly 10 of the cupcakes to her party, and will take either all of the cupcakes of a particular color or none of the cupcakes of that color. How many different combinations of cupcakes could she take to her party? The final Answer is 5
 ### Proof
 If Julie includes one of the colors that cover three cupcakes, she must also include the other color that covers three cupcakes. This is because she must make ten cupcakes total, and all of the other colors cover an even number of cupcakes, so there is no way to make ten with three and some combination of even numbers.
 Thus, if she includes blue and violet, she has four cupcakes left to choose. There are three ways in which she can choose four cupcakes if she chooses colors that cover two (green and orange, green and yellow, or orange and yellow).
 Alternately, she can choose a color that covers four (red). Finally, if she doesn't include any colors that cover three cupcakes, she must choose all of the other cupcakes in order to make ten.
 Thus, Julie has $\boxed{5}$ different combinations of cupcakes.
 *)

theorem
fixes red_cupcakes orange_cupcakes yellow_cupcakes green_cupcakes blue_cupcakes violet_cupcakes total_cupcakes :: nat
assumes h0 : "red_cupcakes = 4"
and h1 : "orange_cupcakes = 2"
and h2 : "yellow_cupcakes = 2"
and h3 : "green_cupcakes = 2"
and h4 : "blue_cupcakes = 3"
and h5 : "violet_cupcakes = 3"
and h6 : "total_cupcakes = red_cupcakes + orange_cupcakes + yellow_cupcakes + green_cupcakes + blue_cupcakes + violet_cupcakes"
and h7 : "10 \<le> total_cupcakes"
shows  "\<exists> n. n = 5 \<and> (\<exists> A B C D E. card A = red_cupcakes \<and> card B = orange_cupcakes \<and> card C = yellow_cupcakes \<and> card D = green_cupcakes \<and> card E = blue_cupcakes \<and> (\<forall> F G H I J. card F = violet_cupcakes \<longrightarrow> (\<exists> K. card K = 10 \<and> ((K \<subseteq> A \<union> B \<union> C \<union> D \<union> E \<union> F \<union> G \<union> H \<union> I \<union> J) \<and> (\<forall> x \<in> K. x \<in> A \<or> x \<in> B \<or> x \<in> C \<or> x \<in> D \<or> x \<in> E \<or> x \<in> F \<or> x \<in> G \<or> x \<in> H \<or> x \<in> I \<or> x \<in> J))))))"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_2.informal problem: There are 4 red, 2 orange, 2 yellow, 2 green, 3 blue, and 3 violet cupcakes. If there are at least 10 total cupcakes, show that there exists a set of 5 cupcakes such that each cupcake comes from a different color group, and the set of 5 cupcakes can be selected from the union of the color groups' sets of cupcakes.

a_3.formal problem:
theorem
fixes red orange yellow green blue violet total :: nat
assumes h0 : "red = 4"
and h1 : "orange = 2"
and h2 : "yellow = 2"
and h3 : "green = 2"
and h4 : "blue = 3"
and h5 : "violet = 3"
and h6 : "total = red + orange + yellow + green + blue + violet"
and h7 : "\<forall> n. n \<in> {red, orange, yellow, green, blue, violet} \<longrightarrow> ((n = 0) \<or> (n = total))"
and h8 : "card {n. n \<in> {red, orange, yellow, green, blue, violet} \<and> n = total} = 10"
shows  "card {x. x \<in> {red, orange, yellow, green, blue, violet} \<and> (\<exists> n. n \<in> {red, orange, yellow, green, blue, violet} \<and> x = 10 * n)} = 5"
a_3.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Julie baked cupcakes for her family at home and for a party at school. She iced 4 cupcakes with red frosting, 2 cupcakes with orange frosting, 2 with yellow, 2 with green, 3 with blue and the last 3 with violet frosting. Each cupcake is iced with exactly one color of frosting. Julie plans to take exactly 10 of the cupcakes to her party, and will take either all of the cupcakes of a particular color or none of the cupcakes of that color. How many different combinations of cupcakes could she take to her party? The final Answer is 5
 ### Proof
 If Julie includes one of the colors that cover three cupcakes, she must also include the other color that covers three cupcakes. This is because she must make ten cupcakes total, and all of the other colors cover an even number of cupcakes, so there is no way to make ten with three and some combination of even numbers.
 Thus, if she includes blue and violet, she has four cupcakes left to choose. There are three ways in which she can choose four cupcakes if she chooses colors that cover two (green and orange, green and yellow, or orange and yellow).
 Alternately, she can choose a color that covers four (red). Finally, if she doesn't include any colors that cover three cupcakes, she must choose all of the other cupcakes in order to make ten.
 Thus, Julie has $\boxed{5}$ different combinations of cupcakes.
 *)

theorem
fixes red orange yellow green blue violet total :: nat
assumes h0 : "red = 4"
and h1 : "orange = 2"
and h2 : "yellow = 2"
and h3 : "green = 2"
and h4 : "blue = 3"
and h5 : "violet = 3"
and h6 : "total = red + orange + yellow + green + blue + violet"
and h7 : "\<forall> n. n \<in> {red, orange, yellow, green, blue, violet} \<longrightarrow> ((n = 0) \<or> (n = total))"
and h8 : "card {n. n \<in> {red, orange, yellow, green, blue, violet} \<and> n = total} = 10"
shows  "card {x. x \<in> {red, orange, yellow, green, blue, violet} \<and> (\<exists> n. n \<in> {red, orange, yellow, green, blue, violet} \<and> x = 10 * n)} = 5"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_3.informal problem: In a set of colored objects, there are 4 red, 2 orange, 2 yellow, 2 green, 3 blue, and 3 violet objects. The total number of objects is the sum of all the colored objects. For each color, the number of objects is either 0 or equal to the total number of objects. There are 10 colors for which the number of objects is equal to the total. How many colors have 10 times the number of objects as one of the other colors? The final answer is 5.

a_4.formal problem:
theorem julie_cupcake_combinations:
fixes red orange yellow green blue violet total :: nat
assumes h0 : "red = 4"
and h1 : "orange = 2"
and h2 : "yellow = 2"
and h3 : "green = 2"
and h4 : "blue = 3"
and h5 : "violet = 3"
and h6 : "total = 10"
shows  "card {combo. (combo \<subseteq> {red, orange, yellow, green, blue, violet}) \<and> (\<Sum>x\<in>combo. x) = total} = 5"
a_4.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Julie baked cupcakes for her family at home and for a party at school. She iced 4 cupcakes with red frosting, 2 cupcakes with orange frosting, 2 with yellow, 2 with green, 3 with blue and the last 3 with violet frosting. Each cupcake is iced with exactly one color of frosting. Julie plans to take exactly 10 of the cupcakes to her party, and will take either all of the cupcakes of a particular color or none of the cupcakes of that color. How many different combinations of cupcakes could she take to her party? The final Answer is 5
 ### Proof
 If Julie includes one of the colors that cover three cupcakes, she must also include the other color that covers three cupcakes. This is because she must make ten cupcakes total, and all of the other colors cover an even number of cupcakes, so there is no way to make ten with three and some combination of even numbers.
 Thus, if she includes blue and violet, she has four cupcakes left to choose. There are three ways in which she can choose four cupcakes if she chooses colors that cover two (green and orange, green and yellow, or orange and yellow).
 Alternately, she can choose a color that covers four (red). Finally, if she doesn't include any colors that cover three cupcakes, she must choose all of the other cupcakes in order to make ten.
 Thus, Julie has $\boxed{5}$ different combinations of cupcakes.
 *)

theorem julie_cupcake_combinations:
fixes red orange yellow green blue violet total :: nat
assumes h0 : "red = 4"
and h1 : "orange = 2"
and h2 : "yellow = 2"
and h3 : "green = 2"
and h4 : "blue = 3"
and h5 : "violet = 3"
and h6 : "total = 10"
shows  "card {combo. (combo \<subseteq> {red, orange, yellow, green, blue, violet}) \<and> (\<Sum>x\<in>combo. x) = total} = 5"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_4.informal problem: Julie has 4 red, 2 orange, 2 yellow, 2 green, 3 blue, and 3 violet cupcakes. She wants to create combinations of exactly 10 cupcakes. How many different combinations can she make? The final answer is 5.

a_5.formal problem:
theorem
fixes red orange yellow green blue violet total :: nat
assumes h0 : "red = 4"
and h1 : "orange = 2"
and h2 : "yellow = 2"
and h3 : "green = 2"
and h4 : "blue = 3"
and h5 : "violet = 3"
and h6 : "total = red + orange + yellow + green + blue + violet"
and h7 : "10 \<le> total"
shows  "\<exists> n. n = 5 \<and> (\<forall> r o y g b v. r + o + y + g + b + v = 10 \<longrightarrow> (\<exists> k. k \<le> n \<and> (\<forall> c. c \<in> {red, orange, yellow, green, blue, violet} \<longrightarrow> k * c \<le> r + o + y + g + b + v)))"
a_5.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Julie baked cupcakes for her family at home and for a party at school. She iced 4 cupcakes with red frosting, 2 cupcakes with orange frosting, 2 with yellow, 2 with green, 3 with blue and the last 3 with violet frosting. Each cupcake is iced with exactly one color of frosting. Julie plans to take exactly 10 of the cupcakes to her party, and will take either all of the cupcakes of a particular color or none of the cupcakes of that color. How many different combinations of cupcakes could she take to her party? The final Answer is 5
 ### Proof
 If Julie includes one of the colors that cover three cupcakes, she must also include the other color that covers three cupcakes. This is because she must make ten cupcakes total, and all of the other colors cover an even number of cupcakes, so there is no way to make ten with three and some combination of even numbers.
 Thus, if she includes blue and violet, she has four cupcakes left to choose. There are three ways in which she can choose four cupcakes if she chooses colors that cover two (green and orange, green and yellow, or orange and yellow).
 Alternately, she can choose a color that covers four (red). Finally, if she doesn't include any colors that cover three cupcakes, she must choose all of the other cupcakes in order to make ten.
 Thus, Julie has $\boxed{5}$ different combinations of cupcakes.
 *)

theorem
fixes red orange yellow green blue violet total :: nat
assumes h0 : "red = 4"
and h1 : "orange = 2"
and h2 : "yellow = 2"
and h3 : "green = 2"
and h4 : "blue = 3"
and h5 : "violet = 3"
and h6 : "total = red + orange + yellow + green + blue + violet"
and h7 : "10 \<le> total"
shows  "\<exists> n. n = 5 \<and> (\<forall> r o y g b v. r + o + y + g + b + v = 10 \<longrightarrow> (\<exists> k. k \<le> n \<and> (\<forall> c. c \<in> {red, orange, yellow, green, blue, violet} \<longrightarrow> k * c \<le> r + o + y + g + b + v)))"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_5.informal problem: In a collection of colored objects, there are 4 red, 2 orange, 2 yellow, 2 green, 3 blue, and 3 violet objects. The total number of objects is at least 10. Find the smallest positive integer $n$ such that for any combination of $r, o, y, g, b,$ and $v$ objects that adds up to 10, there exists a positive integer $k \le n$ such that $k$ times the number of objects of each color is less than or equal to the total number of objects. The final answer is $n=5$.

a_6.formal problem:
theorem cupcakes_combinations:
fixes red orange yellow green blue violet :: nat
assumes h0 : "red = 4"
and h1 : "orange = 2"
and h2 : "yellow = 2"
and h3 : "green = 2"
and h4 : "blue = 3"
and h5 : "violet = 3"
and h6 : " (\<forall> n. n \<in> {red, orange, yellow, green, blue, violet} \<longrightarrow> (n = 0 \<or> n = 10))"
shows  "card {x. x \<in> {red, orange, yellow, green, blue, violet} \<and> x = 10} = 5"
a_6.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Julie baked cupcakes for her family at home and for a party at school. She iced 4 cupcakes with red frosting, 2 cupcakes with orange frosting, 2 with yellow, 2 with green, 3 with blue and the last 3 with violet frosting. Each cupcake is iced with exactly one color of frosting. Julie plans to take exactly 10 of the cupcakes to her party, and will take either all of the cupcakes of a particular color or none of the cupcakes of that color. How many different combinations of cupcakes could she take to her party? The final Answer is 5
 ### Proof
 If Julie includes one of the colors that cover three cupcakes, she must also include the other color that covers three cupcakes. This is because she must make ten cupcakes total, and all of the other colors cover an even number of cupcakes, so there is no way to make ten with three and some combination of even numbers.
 Thus, if she includes blue and violet, she has four cupcakes left to choose. There are three ways in which she can choose four cupcakes if she chooses colors that cover two (green and orange, green and yellow, or orange and yellow).
 Alternately, she can choose a color that covers four (red). Finally, if she doesn't include any colors that cover three cupcakes, she must choose all of the other cupcakes in order to make ten.
 Thus, Julie has $\boxed{5}$ different combinations of cupcakes.
 *)

theorem cupcakes_combinations:
fixes red orange yellow green blue violet :: nat
assumes h0 : "red = 4"
and h1 : "orange = 2"
and h2 : "yellow = 2"
and h3 : "green = 2"
and h4 : "blue = 3"
and h5 : "violet = 3"
and h6 : " (\<forall> n. n \<in> {red, orange, yellow, green, blue, violet} \<longrightarrow> (n = 0 \<or> n = 10))"
shows  "card {x. x \<in> {red, orange, yellow, green, blue, violet} \<and> x = 10} = 5"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_6.informal problem: You have 4 red, 2 orange, 2 yellow, 2 green, 3 blue, and 3 violet cupcakes. You can only have either 0 or 10 cupcakes of each color. How many colors can have exactly 10 cupcakes? The final answer is 5.

a_7.formal problem:
theorem 
fixes red orange yellow green blue violet :: nat
assumes h0 : "red = 4"
and h1 : "orange = 2"
and h2 : "yellow = 2"
and h3 : "green = 2"
and h4 : "blue = 3"
and h5 : "violet = 3"
and h6 : "let total_cupcakes = red + orange + yellow + green + blue + violet in total_cupcakes = 16"
and h7 : "let party_cupcakes = 10 in \<exists>cr co ye gr bl vi. (red = cr \<or> cr = 0) \<and> (orange = co \<or> co = 0) \<and> (yellow = ye \<or> ye = 0) \<and> (green = gr \<or> gr = 0) \<and> (blue = bl \<or> bl = 0) \<and> (violet = vi \<or> vi = 0) \<and> cr + co + ye + gr + bl + vi = party_cupcakes"
shows  "card {cr::nat, co::nat, ye::nat, gr::nat, bl::nat, vi::nat. (red = cr \<or> cr = 0) \<and> (orange = co \<or> co = 0) \<and> (yellow = ye \<or> ye = 0) \<and> (green = gr \<or> gr = 0) \<and> (blue = bl \<or> bl = 0) \<and> (violet = vi \<or> vi = 0) \<and> cr + co + ye + gr + bl + vi = 10} = 5"
a_7.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Julie baked cupcakes for her family at home and for a party at school. She iced 4 cupcakes with red frosting, 2 cupcakes with orange frosting, 2 with yellow, 2 with green, 3 with blue and the last 3 with violet frosting. Each cupcake is iced with exactly one color of frosting. Julie plans to take exactly 10 of the cupcakes to her party, and will take either all of the cupcakes of a particular color or none of the cupcakes of that color. How many different combinations of cupcakes could she take to her party? The final Answer is 5
 ### Proof
 If Julie includes one of the colors that cover three cupcakes, she must also include the other color that covers three cupcakes. This is because she must make ten cupcakes total, and all of the other colors cover an even number of cupcakes, so there is no way to make ten with three and some combination of even numbers.
 Thus, if she includes blue and violet, she has four cupcakes left to choose. There are three ways in which she can choose four cupcakes if she chooses colors that cover two (green and orange, green and yellow, or orange and yellow).
 Alternately, she can choose a color that covers four (red). Finally, if she doesn't include any colors that cover three cupcakes, she must choose all of the other cupcakes in order to make ten.
 Thus, Julie has $\boxed{5}$ different combinations of cupcakes.
 *)

theorem 
fixes red orange yellow green blue violet :: nat
assumes h0 : "red = 4"
and h1 : "orange = 2"
and h2 : "yellow = 2"
and h3 : "green = 2"
and h4 : "blue = 3"
and h5 : "violet = 3"
and h6 : "let total_cupcakes = red + orange + yellow + green + blue + violet in total_cupcakes = 16"
and h7 : "let party_cupcakes = 10 in \<exists>cr co ye gr bl vi. (red = cr \<or> cr = 0) \<and> (orange = co \<or> co = 0) \<and> (yellow = ye \<or> ye = 0) \<and> (green = gr \<or> gr = 0) \<and> (blue = bl \<or> bl = 0) \<and> (violet = vi \<or> vi = 0) \<and> cr + co + ye + gr + bl + vi = party_cupcakes"
shows  "card {cr::nat, co::nat, ye::nat, gr::nat, bl::nat, vi::nat. (red = cr \<or> cr = 0) \<and> (orange = co \<or> co = 0) \<and> (yellow = ye \<or> ye = 0) \<and> (green = gr \<or> gr = 0) \<and> (blue = bl \<or> bl = 0) \<and> (violet = vi \<or> vi = 0) \<and> cr + co + ye + gr + bl + vi = 10} = 5"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_7.informal problem: You have 16 cupcakes: 4 red, 2 orange, 2 yellow, 2 green, 3 blue, and 3 violet. You want to choose 10 cupcakes for a party. In how many ways can you choose the cupcakes for the party, considering that the cupcakes can be chosen from each color or not at all? The final answer is 5.

a_8.formal problem:
theorem
fixes red_cupcakes orange_cupcakes yellow_cupcakes green_cupcakes blue_cupcakes violet_cupcakes :: nat
assumes h0 : "red_cupcakes = 4"
and h1 : "orange_cupcakes = 2"
and h2 : "yellow_cupcakes = 2"
and h3 : "green_cupcakes = 2"
and h4 : "blue_cupcakes = 3"
and h5 : "violet_cupcakes = 3"
and h6 : "red_cupcakes + orange_cupcakes + yellow_cupcakes + green_cupcakes + blue_cupcakes + violet_cupcakes = 16"
and h7 : "red_cupcakes + orange_cupcakes + yellow_cupcakes + green_cupcakes + blue_cupcakes + violet_cupcakes = 16"
shows  "\<exists> n. n = 5 \<and> (\<forall> a b c d e f. a + b + c + d + e + f = 10 \<and> ((a = red_cupcakes) \<or> (a = 0)) \<and> ((b = orange_cupcakes) \<or> (b = 0)) \<and> ((c = yellow_cupcakes) \<or> (c = 0)) \<and> ((d = green_cupcakes) \<or> (d = 0)) \<and> ((e = blue_cupcakes) \<or> (e = 0)) \<and> ((f = violet_cupcakes) \<or> (f = 0)) \<longrightarrow> (\<exists> i \<le> n. \<exists> a_set b_set c_set d_set e_set f_set. finite a_set \<and> finite b_set \<and> finite c_set \<and> finite d_set \<and> finite e_set \<and> finite f_set \<and> (\<forall> x. x \<in> a_set \<longrightarrow> x = a) \<and> (\<forall> y. y \<in> b_set \<longrightarrow> y = b) \<and> (\<forall> z. z \<in> c_set \<longrightarrow> z = c) \<and> (\<forall> w. w \<in> d_set \<longrightarrow> w = d) \<and> (\<forall> u. u \<in> e_set \<longrightarrow> u = e) \<and> (\<forall> v. v \<in> f_set \<longrightarrow> v = f) \<and> card a_set + card b_set + card c_set + card d_set + card e_set + card f_set = 10))"
a_8.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Julie baked cupcakes for her family at home and for a party at school. She iced 4 cupcakes with red frosting, 2 cupcakes with orange frosting, 2 with yellow, 2 with green, 3 with blue and the last 3 with violet frosting. Each cupcake is iced with exactly one color of frosting. Julie plans to take exactly 10 of the cupcakes to her party, and will take either all of the cupcakes of a particular color or none of the cupcakes of that color. How many different combinations of cupcakes could she take to her party? The final Answer is 5
 ### Proof
 If Julie includes one of the colors that cover three cupcakes, she must also include the other color that covers three cupcakes. This is because she must make ten cupcakes total, and all of the other colors cover an even number of cupcakes, so there is no way to make ten with three and some combination of even numbers.
 Thus, if she includes blue and violet, she has four cupcakes left to choose. There are three ways in which she can choose four cupcakes if she chooses colors that cover two (green and orange, green and yellow, or orange and yellow).
 Alternately, she can choose a color that covers four (red). Finally, if she doesn't include any colors that cover three cupcakes, she must choose all of the other cupcakes in order to make ten.
 Thus, Julie has $\boxed{5}$ different combinations of cupcakes.
 *)

theorem
fixes red_cupcakes orange_cupcakes yellow_cupcakes green_cupcakes blue_cupcakes violet_cupcakes :: nat
assumes h0 : "red_cupcakes = 4"
and h1 : "orange_cupcakes = 2"
and h2 : "yellow_cupcakes = 2"
and h3 : "green_cupcakes = 2"
and h4 : "blue_cupcakes = 3"
and h5 : "violet_cupcakes = 3"
and h6 : "red_cupcakes + orange_cupcakes + yellow_cupcakes + green_cupcakes + blue_cupcakes + violet_cupcakes = 16"
and h7 : "red_cupcakes + orange_cupcakes + yellow_cupcakes + green_cupcakes + blue_cupcakes + violet_cupcakes = 16"
shows  "\<exists> n. n = 5 \<and> (\<forall> a b c d e f. a + b + c + d + e + f = 10 \<and> ((a = red_cupcakes) \<or> (a = 0)) \<and> ((b = orange_cupcakes) \<or> (b = 0)) \<and> ((c = yellow_cupcakes) \<or> (c = 0)) \<and> ((d = green_cupcakes) \<or> (d = 0)) \<and> ((e = blue_cupcakes) \<or> (e = 0)) \<and> ((f = violet_cupcakes) \<or> (f = 0)) \<longrightarrow> (\<exists> i \<le> n. \<exists> a_set b_set c_set d_set e_set f_set. finite a_set \<and> finite b_set \<and> finite c_set \<and> finite d_set \<and> finite e_set \<and> finite f_set \<and> (\<forall> x. x \<in> a_set \<longrightarrow> x = a) \<and> (\<forall> y. y \<in> b_set \<longrightarrow> y = b) \<and> (\<forall> z. z \<in> c_set \<longrightarrow> z = c) \<and> (\<forall> w. w \<in> d_set \<longrightarrow> w = d) \<and> (\<forall> u. u \<in> e_set \<longrightarrow> u = e) \<and> (\<forall> v. v \<in> f_set \<longrightarrow> v = f) \<and> card a_set + card b_set + card c_set + card d_set + card e_set + card f_set = 10))"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_8.informal problem: There are 4 red cupcakes, 2 orange cupcakes, 2 yellow cupcakes, 2 green cupcakes, 3 blue cupcakes, and 3 violet cupcakes, totaling 16 cupcakes. If you can only pick 10 cupcakes and no more than the available number of each color, how many different ways can you pick the 10 cupcakes, such that the total number of ways does not exceed 5?

a_9.formal problem:
theorem
fixes red orange yellow green blue violet total :: nat
assumes h0 : "red = 4"
and h1 : "orange = 2"
and h2 : "yellow = 2"
and h3 : "green = 2"
and h4 : "blue = 3"
and h5 : "violet = 3"
and h6 : "total = red + orange + yellow + green + blue + violet"
and h7 : "10 \<le> total"
and h8 : "\<forall>c. c \<in> {red, orange, yellow, green, blue, violet} \<longrightarrow> c = 0 \<or> c = 10"
shows  "card {c. c \<subseteq> {red, orange, yellow, green, blue, violet} \<and> (\<Sum>x\<in>c. x) = 10} = 5"
a_9.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Julie baked cupcakes for her family at home and for a party at school. She iced 4 cupcakes with red frosting, 2 cupcakes with orange frosting, 2 with yellow, 2 with green, 3 with blue and the last 3 with violet frosting. Each cupcake is iced with exactly one color of frosting. Julie plans to take exactly 10 of the cupcakes to her party, and will take either all of the cupcakes of a particular color or none of the cupcakes of that color. How many different combinations of cupcakes could she take to her party? The final Answer is 5
 ### Proof
 If Julie includes one of the colors that cover three cupcakes, she must also include the other color that covers three cupcakes. This is because she must make ten cupcakes total, and all of the other colors cover an even number of cupcakes, so there is no way to make ten with three and some combination of even numbers.
 Thus, if she includes blue and violet, she has four cupcakes left to choose. There are three ways in which she can choose four cupcakes if she chooses colors that cover two (green and orange, green and yellow, or orange and yellow).
 Alternately, she can choose a color that covers four (red). Finally, if she doesn't include any colors that cover three cupcakes, she must choose all of the other cupcakes in order to make ten.
 Thus, Julie has $\boxed{5}$ different combinations of cupcakes.
 *)

theorem
fixes red orange yellow green blue violet total :: nat
assumes h0 : "red = 4"
and h1 : "orange = 2"
and h2 : "yellow = 2"
and h3 : "green = 2"
and h4 : "blue = 3"
and h5 : "violet = 3"
and h6 : "total = red + orange + yellow + green + blue + violet"
and h7 : "10 \<le> total"
and h8 : "\<forall>c. c \<in> {red, orange, yellow, green, blue, violet} \<longrightarrow> c = 0 \<or> c = 10"
shows  "card {c. c \<subseteq> {red, orange, yellow, green, blue, violet} \<and> (\<Sum>x\<in>c. x) = 10} = 5"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_9.informal problem: In a bag, there are 4 red, 2 orange, 2 yellow, 2 green, 3 blue, and 3 violet items. The total number of items in the bag is the sum of all the colors. Each color can either have 0 or 10 items. How many different ways can you choose a combination of items from the bag such that the sum of the items chosen is 10? The final answer is 5.
